abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the 1988 Flood Damage
            Restoration Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. The
            project achieved its main objective, sustainability is
            likely with the development of adequate maintenance
            arrangements, and the performance of both the Bank and
            Borrower was satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, the provision of retroactive
            financing greatly assisted the GOP. Second, "emergency
            response" projects should be supervised more frequently
            by staff specializing in the appropriate disciplines. Third,
            borrower personnel should be given short courses in the
            operation of special accounts, IDA procurement, and
            disbursement procedures. Fourth, supervisory consultants
            should be allowed additional staff-months so that a more
            detailed inspection of civil works under construction is
            possible. Fifth, field teams in charge of civil works may
            require training by supervisory consultants or RMP to
            enhance their competence in checking construction
            techniques. Finally, the scattered nature of restoration
            works, which involves different engineering jurisdictions
            and capabilities, should be taken into account in designing
            special funding arrangements and reimbursement procedures.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will assist the Government
            in the restoration of selected flood damaged irrigation,
            drainage, flood protection, and road infrastructure. The
            loan will provide funds for: (i) restoration of
            infrastructure, including bridges, culverts and other
            related structures; (ii) technical assistance for project
            implementation; and (iii) supervision and administration.
            Only in appropriate cases will rehabilitation involve
            improvement, for instance, providing more vents in bridges
            or enlarging drains for passing future floods. The civil
            works restoration involves about 1.1 billion cubic feet of
            earthwork, in addition to stonework, masonry work,
            bituminous surfacing and structures.
